awd_titl_txt: Towards Deploying a Science-Driven Regional Interoperable Science DMZ
awd_abstract_narration:
High-performance networking is a key enabler of data-intensive science, as researcher collaborations and the sharing/accessibility of data require large, fast transfers of data on a national and international scale. This workshop focuses on regional-level interoperability of campus "Science DMZs", so that researchers can move data to/from their labs and their collaborators, national supercomputer centers or data repositories, traversing multiple, heterogeneous Science DMZs without performance degradation. This capability leverages substantial investments by NSF, DOE and regional networks, and will advance data-intensive scientific discovery by advancing collaborations, making data readily accessible to large communities, and increasing researcher productivity.
 
It has always been a technical challenge to achieve high-speed networking performance between end-points where researchers typically work (instruments, computers, labs). The Science DMZ concept is a major advance in removing these roadblocks within a campus, and interoperability between heterogeneous Science DMZs is the next logical step in successfully addressing performance at both ends. This workshop is to address interoperability challenges by focusing near-term on a few specific scientific applications at a regional level, while laying the foundation for extensibility to other applications and institutions.

The main focus of the Pacific Research Platform (PRP) project is to build a researcher-defined, data-focused network whose requirements are driven by direct engagements with cyberinfrastructure-knowledgeable science teams chosen from the fields of particle physics, astronomy, biomedical sciences, earth sciences, and scalable data visualization. It is a partnership of more than 20 institutions, including four supercomputer centers. The purpose of the workshop titled Building the Pacific Research Platform: A Workshop towards Deploying a Science-Driven Regional ‘Big Data Freeway’ was to bring together representatives from all PRP partner institutions, participating science team members, technical staff, and network architects and implementers to discuss deployment of the PRP and address interoperability of Science DMZ subnetworks at a regional level.

The PRP Workshop was held October 14–16, 2015 at the Qualcomm Institute on the UC San Diego campus. The workshop included an introduction to the PRP from the viewpoint of partner administrators, campus IT managers and the NSF, presentations from researchers and technical experts in science-driver applications describing their needs for high-speed data transfer and their successes and frustrations, and discussions on the networking architecture, policies, tools and security necessary to deploy the PRP.

Workshop attendance was by invitation only and included the PRP member institutions as well as some external collaborators. Approximately 137 people registered for the workshop with about 130 actual attendees – far exceeding the initial projections of 50 attendees. A total of 40 organizations were represented, including virtually all of the initial PRP partners and several organizations that represent outreach for the project. All ten University of California (UC) campuses were represented, as well as the UC Office of the President and UC Agricultural and Natural Resources. Eleven additional US universities were represented, and there was strong representation from regional and national networking organizations, as well as three national labs. Four international organizations (from Amsterdam, Canada, Korea, and Japan) were represented, as well as five members of industry and at least one government agency (NSF).

Through the workshop discussions, it became clear that scientists want to do science, not networking or IT. Therefore, it was recommended that rather than “build it and hope they will come,” the PRP project needs to engage with scientists to capture their unique networking requirements, deploy the system responsive to those requirements, and work with the science projects all along the way to build and use the system. It was suggested that the PRP pursue a strategy of starting with a few “low-hanging fruit” science projects that have specific collaborations and technical requirements, science staff willing and able to work with PRP engineers, and clear scientific advances to be made with higher-performance data transfers. These initial projects will serve as worked examples for solving both social and technical issues in deploying the PRP.

It was also noted that many of the stakeholders often do not work together and almost all have separate funding and management systems in place, which often leads to conflicting interests or priorities. The inclusion of high-level administrators within the PRP partnership (campus CIOs and Vice Chancellors of Research, as well as CENIC and ESnet management) will make resolving potential conflicting interests and priorities easier.
